generatedTitle: Adult Hematopoiesis: Primary Sites and Cell Formation

extractFactDictList.question: Where does the bone marrow produce all of the red blood cells, platelets, and granulocytes?
extractFactDictList.sentence: Bone Marrow: The bone marrow produces all of the red blood cells, platelets, and granulocytes (which make up 60%-70% of white blood cells).

extractFactDictList.question: What makes up 20%-30% of white blood cells and is formed in the lymphatic tissues?
extractFactDictList.sentence: Lymphatic Tissues: Lymphocytes (which make up 20%-30% of white blood cells) are formed in the lymphatic tissues.

extractFactDictList.question: Where are monocytes formed?
extractFactDictList.sentence: Reticuloendothelial Tissue: Monocytes are formed in the reticuloendothelial tissue of the spleen, lymph nodes, liver, and other organs.

extractFactDictList.question: In which organs may hematopoiesis continue in infants and children?
extractFactDictList.sentence: It's important to note that while the bone marrow is the primary site of hematopoiesis in adults, in infants and children, hematopoiesis may also continue in the spleen and liver.
